Subject: English
Strategy: Using the title as a central component in the text’s creation.

Subject: English
Strategy: Strategically developing ideas throughout the text.

Subject: English
Strategy: Revisiting imagery from the stimulus as a way of creating cohesion through the text.

Subject: English
Strategy: Establishing a voice that strategically connected to the reader to achieve the text’s purpose.

Subject: English
Strategy: Using linguistic strategies to amplify and develop ideas.

Subject: English
Strategy: Free writing – some planning is essential, given the limited time available to produce and develop a text.

Subject: English
Strategy: Presenting ideas that were unrelated or minimally related to the Framework.

Subject: English
Strategy: Contorting previously prepared responses in an attempt to connect with the exam title and stimulus.

Subject: English
Strategy: Writing for self, rather than for the reader.

Subject: English
Strategy: Relying solely on plot to convey ideas.

Subject: English
StrategyHeader: Some students appropriated the intellectual or moral status of others, possibly to add a sense of legitimacy to their views.

Subject: English
Strategy: For example, a student may have appropriated the voice of a psychologist when writing about mental health issues.

Subject: English
Strategy: While students are free to adopt a voice within this section, appropriate elaboration of an idea tends to be more compelling than simply claiming expert status.

Subject: English
Strategy: Students are encouraged to consider the many ways in which a position can be legitimised.
